source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: Because of the curvature of the tube. straight specimens were produced by first grinding or milling the pressure tube blank into a flat, $2 \mathrm { - } \mathrm { m m }$ -thick plate. The specimens were then spark-machined from the plate to final dimensions of $4 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ in width and $2 \ \mathrm { m m }$ in thickness, with a gage length of $1 0 ~ \mathrm { m m }$

extra_properties.specimen_dimensions: 4 mm width × 2 mm thickness × 10 mm gage length

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: A procedure was developed using 17- mm curved C(T) specimens [3]. Except for the thickness and the curvature of the tube, the in-plane dimensions of this specimen are in the same proportions as for compact specimens used in the ASTM Standard Test Method for Plane Strain Fracture Toughness of Metallic Materials (E 399-83)
conditions: air, furnace, constant displacement rate 0.25 mm/min

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: Burst tests were performed on $4 6 0 – \mathrm { m m }$ lengths cut from pressure tubes. The length was chosen to be four times the diameter to remove end effects at the midsection
process_step: cut to length, spark-machined slot, mounted instrumentation

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: The $J _ { R }$ curves for the $1 7 - \mathrm { m m }$ specimens were estimated following either ASTM E 813 or ASTM E 1152 using the single-specimen technique

extra_properties.parameters: 2a = crack length, σ_f = flow stress, M = Folias factor, σ_H = hoop stress, E = Young's modulus

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: Measuring the Charpy V-notch (CVN) energy of the pressure tube material is a simpler way to estimate the toughness of the material

extra_properties.cost_comparison: about one tenth of C(T) test cost

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Irradiated Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube material
test_type: tensile test, fracture toughness test, microstructural examination
conditions: neutron irradiation, temperature range: room temperature to 350°C

extra_properties.deformation_behavior: Type A (gentle load decrease after UTS) and Type B (sudden load drop at UTS)
extra_properties.neutron_fluence_effect: tensile properties approach asymptotic values at fluences > 1×10²⁵ n/m²
extra_properties.J_R_curve_stages: Three stages: Stage 1 (low slope), Stage 2 (steep slope), Stage 3 (decreasing slope)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: Lattice parameter measurements obtained by XRD indicate that there is an expansion of the α-phase lattice that reaches a saturation value after fluences of about 1·2×10²⁵ n/m²

evidence_span: About 40% were (Zr,Nb)₃(Fe,Cr)-type and 60% were Zr-85 at.% Nb (β-Nb)

evidence_span: Variation of dislocation density and lattice parameters as a function of position relative to the inlet

extra_properties.dislocation_density_variation: a-types highest at inlet, decreasing ~20% towards outlet
extra_properties.c-type_dislocation: peak at center, splits into partials

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6

extra_properties.ω-phase: present after fabrication and remains after service

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk7

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk10
evidence_span: Controlled composition Zircaloy-2 is defined where nickel and iron are adjusted towards the upper ASTM composition limits and tin is adjusted towards the lower limit
composition_raw: nickel and iron adjusted towards upper ASTM limits, tin adjusted towards lower limit
process_step: hot worked, beta quenched, fabricated using three process schedules with different annealing parameters
conditions: 360°C and 420°C static autoclave tests up to 500 days exposure
corrosion_data: weight gains from 360°C and 420°C static autoclave tests

extra_properties.hydrogen_uptake: depended primarily on corrosion weight gains
